---tab Resumen Aqu√≠ va el texto principal de la nota. Puedes usar **negritas**, *cursivas* y [[enlaces]]. ---tab To My Dear and Loving Husband # An√°lisis: To My Dear and Loving Husband **Autora:** [[Anne Bradstreet]] **A√±o:** c. 1650 (Publicado p√≥stumamente en esta forma en 1678) **Forma:** Dist√≠sticos heroicos (Heroic Couplets) - *Iambic Pentameter* --- ## üìñ 1. Vocabulario Hist√≥rico y Arcaico El poema utiliza un ingl√©s del siglo XVII (Early Modern English). Aqu√≠ est√°n los t√©rminos clave para entender el texto original: * **Thee / Thy:** Pronombre singular para "t√∫" y "tu" (objeto y posesivo). * *Contexto:* Su uso aqu√≠ denota intimidad y cercan√≠a, reservado para Dios o familia muy cercana. * **Ye:** Pronombre plural para "vosotras" o "ustedes". * *Contexto:* *"Compare with me, ye women"* (Comparen conmigo, mujeres). Se dirige a todas las dem√°s mujeres del mundo. * **Doth:** Forma arcaica de "does" (tercera persona singular). * *Contexto:* *"The East doth hold"* (Que el Este posee/tiene). * **Ought:** En este contexto, es una variante ortogr√°fica de **"Aught"**, que significa "cualquier cosa" o "algo". * *Contexto:* *"Nor ought but love..."* (Ni nada excepto amor...). * **Manifold:** En gran n√∫mero, abundantemente, multiplicado. * *Contexto:* *"Reward thee manifold"* (Te recompense con creces). * **Persever:** Forma arcaica de "Persevere" (perseverar). * *Nota de pronunciaci√≥n:* En la √©poca de Bradstreet, se acentuaba en la segunda s√≠laba (*per-SEV-er*), por lo que rimaba perfectamente con "ever". --- ## üîç 2. An√°lisis de Met√°foras e Im√°genes ### A. La Unidad Matrimonial ("If ever two were one...") > *"If ever two were one, then surely we."* * **Referencia B√≠blica:** Alude a Mateo 19:6 ("y los dos ser√°n una sola carne"). * **Significado:** Establece la uni√≥n espiritual y f√≠sica completa. No son dos individuos separados, sino una entidad √∫nica. Es una afirmaci√≥n audaz de armon√≠a perfecta. ### B. Valor Material vs. Valor Espiritual ("Mines of gold...") > *"I prize thy love more than whole mines of gold / Or all the riches that the East doth hold."* * **La Met√°fora:** Compara el amor con la riqueza comercial m√°s codiciada del siglo XVII. * **Contexto Hist√≥rico:** "The East" (Las Indias Orientales) era la fuente de especias, seda y oro. Era el s√≠mbolo m√°ximo de riqueza ex√≥tica y material. * **Significado:** Bradstreet rechaza el materialismo. La riqueza del Nuevo Mundo o del Viejo Mundo no tiene valor comparada con su esposo. ### C. La Sed y el Fuego ("Rivers cannot quench") > *"My love is such that rivers cannot quench"* * **La Imagen:** El amor se presenta como un fuego tan intenso o una sed tan grande que ni todos los r√≠os pueden apagarlo o saciarla. * **Referencia:** Posible alusi√≥n al Cantar de los Cantares (Song of Solomon 8:7): *"Las muchas aguas no podr√°n apagar el amor, ni lo ahogar√°n los r√≠os"*. Esto eleva su amor terrenal a un nivel casi sagrado. ### D. La Econom√≠a del Amor ("Repay", "Recompense") Bradstreet utiliza t√©rminos **financieros** para describir sus sentimientos: * *"Prize"* (Valorar/Tasar) * *"Recompense"* (Recompensar/Pagar) * *"Repay"* (Repagar/Devolver deuda) * **An√°lisis:** Ella siente que el amor de su esposo es tan inmenso que ella est√° en "deuda". Como no tiene "capital" emocional suficiente para pagarle (porque √©l le da demasiado), pide a los cielos ("The heavens") que salden la deuda por ella ("reward thee manifold"). --- ## ‚öñÔ∏è 3. La Paradoja Final (El cierre) > *"That when we live no more, we may live ever."* Este es un cierre cl√°sico puritano que resuelve la tensi√≥n entre amar el mundo y amar a Dios. 1. **La contradicci√≥n aparente:** ¬øC√≥mo podemos vivir si ya no vivimos? 2. **La soluci√≥n cristiana:** Si se aman fielmente en la Tierra (siguiendo el mandato divino), ser√°n recompensados con la **Vida Eterna** en el cielo. 3. **Conclusi√≥n:** La muerte no es el final del amor, sino la puerta hacia su eternidad. --- ## üí° Notas para la clase * **Tono:** A diferencia del estereotipo puritano (austero, fr√≠o), este poema es **apasionado, confidente y sensual**. * **Estructura:** Observar el uso de **An√°fora** en las primeras tres l√≠neas ("If ever... If ever... If ever...") que construye un argumento l√≥gico creciente. ---tab Im√°genes ![[mi-imagen.png]]Anne Bradstreet (1612‚Äì1672) es una de las figuras m√°s importantes de la literatura colonial temprana y es reconocida hist√≥ricamente como la primera persona (hombre o mujer) en ser publicada como poeta en las colonias brit√°nicas de Norteam√©rica. Origen: Naci√≥ en Inglaterra en una familia culta y acomodada. Recibi√≥ una educaci√≥n muy superior a la de la mayor√≠a de las mujeres de su √©poca.
Migraci√≥n: En 1630, a los 18 a√±os, emigr√≥ a Am√©rica a bordo del barco Arbella como parte de la gran migraci√≥n puritana a la Colonia de la Bah√≠a de Massachusetts. Estatus: Tanto su padre (Thomas Dudley) como su esposo (Simon Bradstreet) fueron gobernadores de la colonia, lo que la situaba en la √©lite social, aunque esto no la eximi√≥ de las durezas de la vida pionera (enfermedades, incendios, riesgos de parto). El hito: Su libro, The Tenth Muse Lately Sprung Up in America (1650), fue publicado en Londres (supuestamente por su cu√±ado y sin su conocimiento previo). Fue un √©xito inmediato en el Viejo Mundo. Dos voces: P√∫blica/Formal: Sus primeros poemas eran largos, hist√≥ricos y filos√≥ficos, dise√±ados para demostrar que una mujer pod√≠a tener intelecto y raz√≥n.
Privada/√çntima: Los poemas (To My Dear and Loving Husband, In Reference to her Children) pertenecen a su etapa m√°s madura y personal. Son considerados hoy en d√≠a su mejor trabajo porque rompen con el estereotipo puritano fr√≠o y muestran emociones humanas profundas, miedo a la muerte y amor apasionado. Al leer los textos que transcribiste, notar√°s estos temas recurrentes: El amor matrimonial: En contra de la creencia popular de que los puritanos rechazaban la pasi√≥n, Bradstreet describe un amor profundo, f√≠sico y espiritual hacia su esposo ("If ever two were one, then surely we"). La maternidad y la ansiedad: Dado que la mortalidad era alta, muchos de sus poemas (como Before the Birth of One of Her Children) son testamentos o despedidas anticipadas, mostrando la ansiedad real de morir en el parto o de perder a sus hijos. Fe vs. Apego Terrenal: Existe una tensi√≥n constante en su obra. Como puritana, deb√≠a centrarse en Dios y el cielo, pero sus poemas revelan lo mucho que amaba el mundo, a su esposo y a sus hijos ("birds"), y lo dif√≠cil que le resultaba la idea de soltarlos. Bradstreet es fundamental porque nos da una ventana √∫nica a la vida dom√©stica femenina del siglo XVII. No escribe solo sobre teolog√≠a, sino sobre el miedo a que su casa se incendie, el dolor de que sus hijos se vayan de casa y el amor rom√°ntico, humanizando una √©poca hist√≥rica que a menudo vemos como r√≠gida y distante.By Anne BradstreetIf ever two were one, then surely we. If ever man were loved by wife, then thee. If ever wife was happy in a man, Compare with me, ye women, if you can. I prize thy love more than whole mines of gold, Or all the riches that the East doth hold. My love is such that rivers cannot quench, Nor ought but love from thee give recompense. Thy love is such I can no way repay; The heavens reward thee manifold, I pray. Then while we live, in love let‚Äôs so persever, That when we live no more, we may live ever. Source: The Complete Works of Anne Bradstreet (1981) Subjects: Living, Marriage & Companionship, Love, Romantic Love, RelationshipsBy Anne BradstreetAll things within this fading world hath end, Adversity doth still our joyes attend; No ties so strong, no friends so dear and sweet, But with death‚Äôs parting blow is sure to meet. The sentence past is most irrevocable, A common thing, yet oh inevitable. How soon, my Dear, death may my steps attend, How soon‚Äôt may be thy Lot to lose thy friend, We are both ignorant, yet love bids me These farewell lines to recommend to thee, That when that knot‚Äôs untied that made us one, I may seem thine, who in effect am none. And if I see not half my dayes that‚Äôs due, What nature would, God grant to yours and you; The many faults that well you know I have Let be interr‚Äôd in my oblivious grave; If any worth or virtue were in me, Let that live freshly in thy memory And when thou feel‚Äôst no grief, as I no harms, Yet love thy dead, who long lay in thine arms. And when thy loss shall be repaid with gains Look to my little babes, my dear remains. And if thou love thyself, or loved‚Äôst me, These o protect from step Dames injury. And if chance to thine eyes shall bring this verse, With some sad sighs honour my absent Herse; And kiss this paper for thy loves dear sake, Who with salt tears this last Farewel did take.By Anne BradstreetI had eight birds hatcht in one nest, Four Cocks were there, and Hens the rest. I nurst them up with pain and care, No cost nor labour did I spare Till at the last they felt their wing, Mounted the Trees and learned to sing. Chief of the Brood then took his flight To Regions far and left me quite. My mournful chirps I after send Till he return, or I do end. Leave not thy nest, thy Dame and Sire, Fly back and sing amidst this Quire. My second bird did take her flight And with her mate flew out of sight. Southward they both their course did bend, And Seasons twain they there did spend, Till after blown by Southern gales They Norward steer‚Äôd with filled sails. A prettier bird was no where seen, Along the Beach, among the treen. I have a third of colour white On whom I plac‚Äôd no small delight, Coupled with mate loving and true, Hath also bid her Dame adieu. And where Aurora first appears, She now hath percht to spend her years. One to the Academy flew To chat among that learned crew. Ambition moves still in his breast That he might chant above the rest, Striving for more than to do well, That nightingales he might excell. My fifth, whose down is yet scarce gone, Is ‚Äòmongst the shrubs and bushes flown And as his wings increase in strength On higher boughs he‚Äôll perch at length. My other three still with me nest Until they‚Äôre grown, then as the rest, Or here or there, they‚Äôll take their flight, As is ordain‚Äôd, so shall they light. If birds could weep, then would my tears Let others know what are my fears Lest this my brood some harm should catch And be surpris‚Äôd for want of watch Whilst pecking corn and void of care They fall un‚Äôwares in Fowler‚Äôs snare; Or whilst on trees they sit and sing Some untoward boy at them do fling, Or whilst allur‚Äôd with bell and glass The net be spread and caught, alas; Or lest by Lime-twigs they be foil‚Äôd; Or by some greedy hawks be spoil‚Äôd. O would, my young, ye saw my breast And knew what thoughts there sadly rest. Great was my pain when I you bred, Great was my care when I you fed. Long did I keep you soft and warm And with my wings kept off all harm. My cares are more, and fears, than ever, My throbs such now as ‚Äòfore were never. Alas, my birds, you wisdom want Of perils you are ignorant. Oft times in grass, on trees, in flight, Sore accidents on you may light. O to your safety have an eye, So happy may you live and die. Mean while, my days in tunes I‚Äôll spend Till my weak lays with me shall end. In shady woods I‚Äôll sit and sing And things that past, to mind I‚Äôll bring. Once young and pleasant, as are you, But former toys (no joys) adieu! My age I will not once lament But sing, my time so near is spent, And from the top bough take my flight Into a country beyond sight Where old ones instantly grow young And there with seraphims set song. No seasons cold, nor storms they see But spring lasts to eternity. When each of you shall in your nest Among your young ones take your rest, In chirping languages oft them tell You had a Dame that lov‚Äôd you well, That did what could be done for young And nurst you up till you were strong And ‚Äòfore she once would let you fly She shew‚Äôd you joy and misery, Taught what was good, and what was ill, What would save life, and what would kill. Thus gone, amongst you I may live, And dead, yet speak and counsel give. Farewell, my birds, farewell, adieu, I happy am, if well with you. Source: The Complete Works of Anne Bradstreet (1981) Subjects: Living, Parenthood, Time & Brevity, Relationships, Family & Ancestors, Nature, Animals, Weather, Social Commentaries, Gender & Sexuality Poet's Region: U.S., New England Poetic Terms: Couplet

item.title: 02.3_1630 - Winthrop, John - A Model of Christian Charity
item.description:
02.4_Vocabulario y Conceptos Hist√≥ricos - Winthrop John - A Model of Christian CharityJohn Winthrop, "A Modell of Christian Charity"New England's Puritans dissented not only from the Church of England, but from England's social and political order as well. Seeking alternatives to established institutions, they turned on the one hand to Scripture and on the other to their common experience for precedents. Of this extraordinarily learned and articulate group (the Massachusetts Bay Colony in the seventeenth century boasted more college graduates per capita than England itself), few gave more careful thought to the purposes of the Puritans' "errand into the wilderness" or to the proper foundations for the colony's institutions than, John Winthrop (1588-1649).Winthrop was a representative of the new gentry that flourished under the Tudor regime. His grandfather, Adam Winthrop, was a country boy who went to London, made a fortune as a clothier, and then purchased a manor (one of the many properties seized by Henry VIII from the church). His son, also named Adam, trained as a lawyer, but spent his life farming and governing his estate in Suffolk. The habit of governing others came naturally to John Winthrop. After attending Trinity College, Cambridge for two years, he returned home, where he was appointed Justice of the Peace and, a few years later, steward -- in which capacity he acted as his father's chief financial and administrative officer.Despite his privileged position, John Winthrop, like many other educated Englishmen of the period, became increasingly disenchanted with corrupt and oppressive Stuart monarchy. When Charles I decided in the spring of 1629 to rule without parliamentary consent, imprisoned Puritan parliamentary leaders, and banned Puritans from the practice of law, Winthrop decided to emigrate.While en route to New England in 1630, on board the Arabella, Winthrop wrote an essay on charity (which he presumably preached as a sermon) which sought to apply scriptural virtues to the peculiar circumstances and challenges the colonists would face in creating their new social and political order. A number of themes which become central to American philanthropic traditions are first articulated here: 1) efforts to reconcile the problem of spiritual and political equality with economic inequality; 2) concerns about the relations between the good of individuals and the good of the community; 3) the conception of community as a voluntary -- contractual -- bond between individuals; 4) a focus on the particular obligations of the rich towards the poor; 4) the conception of mission as the basis for formulating specific institutional goals and objectives.It is important to note that Winthrop does not mention private institutions: he, like many Puritans, rejected the idea of endowed institutions because of their association with Stuart corruption. For him, charity retains an interpersonal rather than an institutional emphasis. Further, he assumes that the work of society will be done by public institutions of church and State. Notably, Winthrop did not suggest that charity should extend beyond the convenanted group of believers. The notion of universal benevolence would have to wait until a more enlightened age.A Modell of Christian CharityWrittenOn board the Arabella,On the Atlantic Ocean.By the Honorable JOHN WINTHROP Esquire.In his passage, (with a great Company of Religious People,of which Christian Tribes he was the Brave Leader and famousGovernor;) from the Island of Great Brittaine, to New Englandin North America. Anno 1630.God Almightie in his most holy and wise providence hath so disposed of the Condicion of mankind, as in all times some must be rich some poore, some high and eminent in power and dignitie; others meane and in subjection.THE REASON HEREOF.
Reas: First, to hold conformity with the rest of his works, being delighted to shewe forthe the glory of his wisdome in the variety and difference of the Creatures and the glory of his power, in ordering all these differences for the preservacion and good of the whole, and the glory of his greatnes that as it is the glory of princes to have many officers, soe this great King will have many Stewards counting himselfe more honored in dispenceing his guifts to man by man, than if he did it by his owne immediate hand. Reas: Secondly, That he might have the more occasion to manifest the work of his Spirit: first, upon the wicked in moderateing and restraineing them; so that the riche and mighty should not eate upp the poore, mor the poore, and dispised rise up against their superiours, and shake off theire yoake; 2ly in the regenerate in exerciseing his graces in them, as in the greate ones, their love mercy, gentlenes, temperance etc., in the poore and inferior sorte, theire faithe patience, obedience, etc.Explicaci√≥nEsta secci√≥n es fundamental porque Winthrop est√° respondiendo a la pregunta teol√≥gica: "¬øPor qu√© Dios permite (o dise√±a) que haya desigualdad social, con unos muy ricos y otros muy pobres?" Aqu√≠ te explico punto por punto lo que Winthrop argumenta en esos dos p√°rrafos: Winthrop argumenta que la desigualdad es una decisi√≥n est√©tica y administrativa de Dios. La Gloria de la Variedad: Dios se deleita en la diversidad de sus criaturas (animales, plantas, estrellas). De la misma manera, quiere ver variedad en la humanidad (diferentes niveles de riqueza y poder) para mostrar la gloria de su sabidur√≠a. La Preservaci√≥n del Todo: Winthrop cree que estas diferencias est√°n ordenadas para "la preservaci√≥n y el bien del todo". Es decir, la sociedad funciona como una m√°quina donde cada pieza tiene un tama√±o diferente para que el mecanismo funcione. La Met√°fora del Rey y los Mayordomos (Stewards): Esta es la parte clave. Winthrop dice que un Pr√≠ncipe glorioso no hace todo el trabajo √©l mismo; tiene muchos "oficiales". De igual modo, Dios (el Gran Rey) usa a los ricos como "Stewards" (Administradores/Mayordomos). El concepto: Dios podr√≠a dar dinero directamente a los pobres por un milagro ("his owne immediate hand"), pero prefiere darle el dinero a los ricos para que ellos lo distribuyan ("dispenceing his guifts to man by man"). Esto honra m√°s a Dios porque crea una cadena de servicio. Aqu√≠ Winthrop explica la funci√≥n moral de la desigualdad. Dios usa la diferencia de clases para controlar a los malvados y perfeccionar a los buenos ("los regenerados"). Winthrop tiene una visi√≥n pesimista de la naturaleza humana. Sin el control divino y la estructura social: Los Ricos: Se comer√≠an vivos a los pobres ("eate upp the poore"). Es una met√°fora de explotaci√≥n extrema. Los Pobres: Se rebelar√≠an violentamente contra sus superiores ("rise up against their superiours") y sacudir√≠an su yugo ("shake off theire yoake"). Conclusi√≥n: La estructura social, mantenida por el Esp√≠ritu de Dios, evita que la sociedad se convierta en una guerra civil constante. Para los "regenerados" (los buenos cristianos), la desigualdad es necesaria porque sin ella no podr√≠an practicar ciertas virtudes espec√≠ficas: En resumen: Si todos fueran ricos, nadie necesitar√≠a misericordia. Si todos fueran pobres, nadie podr√≠a ejercer la caridad. Winthrop dice que Dios cre√≥ la desigualdad para obligar a los humanos a necesitarse unos a otros y as√≠ crear lazos sagrados (el "tejido" o knit del que hablar√° m√°s adelante). Reas: Thirdly, That every man might have need of other, and from thence they might all be knitt more nearly together in the Bond of brotherly affeccion. . . . The deffinition which the Scripture gives us of love is this Love is the bond of perfection. First, it is a bond, or ligament. 2ly, it makes the worke perfect. There is no body but consistes of partes and that which knitts these partes together gives the body its perfeccion, because it makes eache parte soe continguous to other as thereby doe mutually participate with eache other, both in strengthe and infirmity in pleasure and paine, to instance in the most perfect of all bodies, Christ and his church make one body: the severall partes of this body considered aparte before they were united were as disproportionate and as much disordering as so many contrary quallities or elements but when christ comes and by his spirit and love knitts all these partes to himselfe and each to other, it is become the most perfect and best proportioned body in the world. . . .Explicaci√≥n Winthrop presenta la tercera raz√≥n ("3. Reas: Thirdly") de por qu√© existen ricos y pobres: El Prop√≥sito de la Escasez: La raz√≥n de la desigualdad es "que cada hombre pueda tener necesidad del otro" (That every man might have need of other). El Resultado: Al necesitarse mutuamente (el pobre necesita ayuda, el rico necesita a alguien a quien servir), se crea un v√≠nculo inevitable. De esta necesidad nace el "V√≠nculo de afecto fraternal" (Bond of brotherly affeccion). Interpretaci√≥n: Si todos fueran ricos y poderosos, vivir√≠an aislados en su independencia. La desigualdad fuerza la comunidad. Winthrop ofrece una definici√≥n casi m√©dica o anat√≥mica del amor, basada en las Escrituras (The deffinition which the Scripture gives us of love): El Amor es un Tejido Conectivo: Lo define expl√≠citamente como un "ligamento" (bond, or ligament). Funci√≥n del Ligamento: Un cuerpo se compone de partes. Sin ligamentos, esas partes ser√≠an solo un mont√≥n de huesos y carne sueltos. El amor es lo que "teje" (knitts) estas partes juntas y le da al cuerpo su perfecci√≥n. Contig√ºidad y Empat√≠a: El ligamento hace que las partes est√©n tan unidas (contiguous) que "participan mutuamente" (mutually participate) en lo que le pasa a la otra. Si una parte siente dolor (paine) o placer (pleasure), o tiene fuerza (strengthe) o enfermedad (infirmity), el resto del cuerpo lo siente. Esto es una llamada a la empat√≠a radical. Winthrop usa el ejemplo teol√≥gico m√°ximo para ilustrar su punto social: "el cuerpo m√°s perfecto de todos, Cristo y su iglesia hacen un solo cuerpo" (the most perfect of all bodies, Christ and his church make one body). Antes de la Uni√≥n (Caos): Consideradas por separado, las partes (las personas) son "desproporcionadas" y "desordenadas" (disproportionate and as much disordering), como elementos contrarios chocando entre s√≠. Un individuo sin comunidad es un caos. Despu√©s de la Uni√≥n (Perfecci√≥n): Cuando Cristo viene y, mediante su Esp√≠ritu y amor, "teje" (knitts) todas estas partes consigo mismo y entre ellas, se convierte en el cuerpo "mejor proporcionado del mundo". Here in are 4 things to be propounded: first the persons, 2ly, the worke, 3ly, the end, 4ly, the meanes. For the persons, wee are a Company professiong our selves fellow members of Christ. In which respect onely though wee were absent from eache other many miles, and had our imploymentes as farre distant, yet wee ought to account ourselves knitt toether by this bond of love, and live in the Aqu√≠ tienes la transcripci√≥n de las p√°ginas restantes (3, 4, 5 y 6). He mantenido la ortograf√≠a y puntuaci√≥n del ingl√©s antiguo (por ejemplo: "prividence", "Condicion", "2ly", "Citty") tal como aparece en el documento original. Explicaci√≥n Finalmente, Winthrop baja de la teolog√≠a a la realidad de su viaje: Qui√©nes son: Se definen como una Compa√±√≠a que profesa ser "miembros compa√±eros de Cristo" (fellow members of Christ). La Regla de la Distancia: Argumenta que, gracias a este "ligamento", la distancia f√≠sica no importa. Aunque est√©n ausentes el uno del otro por muchas millas (absent from eache other many miles), deben considerarse "tejidos juntos" (knitt toether) por este v√≠nculo de amor. En resumen: Winthrop est√° diciendo que la sociedad que est√°n fundando no es una empresa comercial ni una simple ciudad; es un organismo vivo. Si cortas el "ligamento" (el amor/caridad) ignorando las necesidades del vecino, el cuerpo se desmorona y muere.excercise of it, if wee would have the comforte of our being in Christ. . . .2ly. for the worke wee have in hand, it is by mutuall consent through a speciall overruleing providence, and amore then an ordinary approbation of the Churches of Christ to seeke out a place ofCohabitation and Consorteshipp under a due forme of Government both civall and ecclesiasticall. In such cases as this the care of the publique must oversway all private respects, by which not onely conscience, but meare Civil policy doth bind1e us; for it is a true rule that perticuler estates cannott subsist in the ruine of the publique.SummaryEsta secci√≥n es el "plan de acci√≥n" pr√°ctico y espiritual de Winthrop. Aqu√≠ define qu√© van a hacer, por qu√© lo hacen y c√≥mo deben comportarse para sobrevivir. "seeke out a place of Cohabitation and Consorteshipp under a due forme of Government both civall and ecclesiasticall." Winthrop define la colonia no como un campamento comercial, sino como una sociedad estructurada: Cohabitation and Consorteshipp (Convivencia y Consorcio): No son individuos aislados buscando fortuna, sino socios que han acordado vivir juntos ("Consorteshipp"). Government both civall and ecclesiasticall (Gobierno tanto civil como eclesi√°stico): Winthrop establece desde el principio que necesitar√°n dos tipos de autoridad: Leyes civiles (magistrados, cortes) para el orden p√∫blico. Leyes eclesi√°sticas (iglesia) para el orden espiritual. La Regla de Oro Pol√≠tica: Justo despu√©s, establece la prioridad absoluta: "the care of the publique must oversway all private respects". El bien p√∫blico est√° por encima del inter√©s privado, porque si la colonia ("lo p√∫blico") se arruina, nadie podr√° salvar su propiedad privada ("particular estates"). 3ly. The end is to improve our lives to doe more service to the Lord the comforte and encrease of the body of christe whereof wee are members that our selves and posterity may be the better preserved from the Common corrupcions of this evill world to serve the Lord and worke out our Salvacion under the power and purity of his holy Ordinances.Summary "preserved from the Common corrupcions of this evill world" El objetivo ("The end") no es la riqueza, sino la pureza espiritual. Quieren mejorar sus vidas para servir m√°s a Dios y protegerse a s√≠ mismos y a sus hijos ("posterity") de la corrupci√≥n moral que ve√≠an en Europa e Inglaterra. Buscan vivir bajo "Ordenanzas santas".4ly. for the meanes whereby this must be effected, they are 2fold, a Conformity with the worke and end we aim at, these wee see are extraordinary, therefore wee must not content our selves with usuall ordinary meanes whatsoever wee did or ought to have done when wee lived in England, the same must we doe and more allsoe where we goe. . . .Summary Winthrop advierte que, como el objetivo es extraordinario, los medios tambi√©n deben serlo ("extraordinary"). No basta con ser "buenos cristianos" como lo eran en Inglaterra; deben hacer m√°s. "we must entertaine each other in brotherly Affeccion" Afecto Fraternal: Deben tratarse como familia. Sacrificio Econ√≥mico: Deben estar dispuestos a recortar sus propios excesos ("abridge our selves of our superfluities") para suplir las necesidades de los dem√°s. "make others Condicions our owne rejoyce together" Empat√≠a Total: La frase completa es "make others Condicions our owne, rejoyce together" (hacer nuestras las condiciones de los otros, regocijarnos juntos). Significa que si tu vecino sufre, t√∫ debes sentir ese sufrimiento como propio; si √©l celebra, t√∫ celebras. No hay indiferencia permitida.
. . . wee must be knitt together in this worke as one man, we must entertaine each other in brotherly Affeccion, we must be willing to abridge our selves of our superfluities, for the suppy of others necessities, we must uphold a familiar Commerce together in meekenes, gentlenes, patience and liberallity, wee must delight in eache other, make others Condicions our owne rejoyce together, allwayes haveing before our eyes== our Commission and Community== in the worke. . . . for wee must Consider that wee shall be as a Citty upon a Hill , the eies of all people are uppon us; soe that if wee shall deale falsely with our god in this worke wee have undertaken and soe cause him to withdrawe his present help from us, wee shall be made a story and a by-word through the world, we shall open the mouthes of enemies to speake evill of the wayes of god and all professours for Gods sake; wee shall shame the faces of many of gods worthy servants, and cause theire pra31yers to be turned into Curses upon us till we be consumed out of the good land whether we are going. . . .Summary "always haveing before our eyes our Commission and Community in the worke" Commission (La Comisi√≥n): Winthrop ve esto como un contrato legal con Dios. Dios les ha dado el permiso y los recursos para ir; ellos a cambio prometen construir una sociedad santa. El Riesgo: Si rompen el contrato ("deale falsely with our god"), Dios retirar√° su ayuda y perecer√°n. "wee shall be as a Citty upon a Hill, the eies of all people are uppon us" Esta es la conclusi√≥n famosa y terrible: Visibilidad Total: Ser una "Ciudad sobre una Colina" no es un premio, es una responsabilidad de alto riesgo. Significa que no pueden esconderse. El Juicio Mundial: "Los ojos de todos los pueblos est√°n sobre nosotros". Si tienen √©xito: Glorifican a Dios. Si fracasan: Se convertir√°n en una "historia y un refr√°n" (story and a by-word) de burla por todo el mundo. Avergonzar√°n a Dios y sus oraciones se convertir√°n en maldiciones hasta que sean "consumidos" (destruidos) de la tierra. Resumen: Winthrop les est√° diciendo: "Hemos firmado un contrato estricto con Dios. Si nos cuidamos unos a otros (amor fraternal) y ponemos a la comunidad primero, sobreviviremos y seremos un ejemplo. Si somos ego√≠stas, todo el mundo nos ver√° fracasar y moriremos".Source: Edmund S. item.title: 02.1_1623 - Frethorne, Richard - Letter to His Parents
item.description: [...] colonization in the early seventeenth century. Combatting homesickness, disease, hunger, discomfort, and isolation, Frethorne and his fellow settlers struggled to make a success of their fledgling community. As might be expected, many longed to be "redeemed out of Egypt" and return to their former lives across the Atlantic. Frethorne's correspondence reveals the poignancy of the struggle for survival waged by the class of indentured servants in the new world. ‚Äî Lisbeth Cohen, Montana State University Loving and kind father and mother:My most humble duty remembered to you, hoping in God of your good health, as I myself am at the making hereof. This is to let you understand that I your child am in a most heavy case by reason of the nature of the country, [which] is such that it causeth much sickness, as the scurvy and the bloody flux and diverse other diseases, which maketh the body very poor and weak. And when we are sick there is nothing to comfort us; for since I came out of the ship I never ate anything but peas, and loblollie (that is, water gruel). As for deer or venison I never saw any since I came into this land. There is indeed some fowl, but we are not allowed to go and get it, but must work hard both early and late for a mess of water gruel and a mouthful of bread and beef. A mouthful of bread for a penny loaf must serve for four men which is most pitiful....People cry out day and night‚ÄîOh! that they were in England without their limbs‚Äîand would not care to lose any limb to be England again, yea, though they beg from door to door. For we live in fear of the enemy every hour, yet we have had a combat with them on the Sunday before Shrovetide,^1 and we took two alive and made slaves of them. But it was by policy, for we are in great danger; for our plantation is very weak by reason of the death and sickness of our company. For we came but twenty for the merchants, and they are half dead just; and we look every hour when two more should go. Yet there came some four other men yet to live with us, of which there is but one alive; and our Lieutenant is dead, and his father and his brother. And there was some five or six of the last year‚Äôs twenty, of which there is but three left, so that we are fain to get other men to plant with us; and yet we are but 32 to fight against 3000 if they should come. And the nighest help that we have is ten miles of us, and when the rogues overcame this place last they slew 80 persons. How then shall we do, for we lie even in their teeth? They may easily take us, but that God is merciful and can save with few as well as with many, as he showed to Gilead.^2 ...And I have nothing to comfort me, nor there is nothing to be gotten here but sickness and death, except that one had money to lay out in some things for profit. But I have nothing at all‚Äîno, not a shirt to my back but two rags (2), nor no clothes but one poor suit, nor but one pair of shoes, but one pair of stockings, but one cap, but two bands. My cloak is stolen by one of my own fellows, and to his dying hour [he] would not tell me what he did with it; but some of my fellows saw him have butter and beef out of a ship, which my cloak, I doubt [not], paid for. So that I have not a penny, nor a penny worth, to help me to either spice or sugar or strong waters, without the which one cannot live here. For as strong beer in1 England doth fatten and strengthen them, so water here doth wash and weaken these here [and] only keeps life and soul together. 2But I am not half a quarter so strong as I was in England, and all is for want of victuals; for I do protest unto you that I have eaten more in [one] day at home than I have allowed me here for a week. You have given more than my day‚Äôs allowance to a beggar at the door: and if Mr. Jackson had not relieved me, I should be in a poor case. But he like a father and she like a loving mother doth still help me.3...Goodman Jackson pitied me and made me a cabin to lie in... which comforted me more than peas or water gruel. Oh, they be very godly folks, and love me very well, and will do anything for me. And he much marvelled that you would send me a servant to the Company; he saith I had been better knocked on the head. And indeed so I find it now, to my great grief and misery; and saith that if you love me you will redeem me suddenly, for which I do entreat and beg. And if you cannot get the merchants to redeem me for some little money, then for God‚Äôs sake get a gathering or entreat some good folks to lay out some little sum of money in meal and cheese and butter and beef. Any eating meat will yield great profit. Oil and vinegar is very good; but, father, there is great loss in leaking. But for God‚Äôs sake send beef and cheese and butter, or the more of one sort and none of another. But if you send cheese, it must be very old cheese; and at the cheesemonger‚Äôs you may buy very good cheese for two pence farthing or halfpenny, that will be liked very well. But if you send cheese, you must have a care how you pack it in barrels; and you must put cooper‚Äôs chips between every cheese, or else the heat of the hold will rot them. And look whatsoever you send me‚Äîbe it never so much‚Äîlook, what[ever] I make of it, I will deal truly with you. I will send it over and beg the profit to redeem me; and if I die before it come, I have entreated Goodman Jackson to send you the worth of it, who hath promised he will....Explicaci√≥nEsta es una de las partes m√°s conmovedoras y reveladoras de la carta. Aqu√≠, Richard Frethorne deja de lado las descripciones generales de la colonia para hablar de su estrategia personal de supervivencia y lanzar una s√∫plica desesperada (y manipuladora) a sus padres. Aqu√≠ te explico los puntos clave de este fragmento desglosados por temas: Frethorne introduce a un tal Sr. Jackson (Goodman era un t√≠tulo para hombres respetables pero no nobles). El contraste: Mientras sus propios padres lo enviaron a sufrir, este extra√±o lo "compadeci√≥" (pitied me), le construy√≥ una caba√±a y lo trat√≥ como a un hijo. La cr√≠tica indirecta: Frethorne usa a Jackson para criticar a sus padres sin hacerlo directamente. Dice que Jackson "se maravill√≥" de que sus padres lo hubieran enviado como sirviente y dijo que "habr√≠a sido mejor que me golpearan en la cabeza" (better knocked on the head). Es una forma brutal de decir: "Enviarme aqu√≠ fue una sentencia de muerte, y hasta un extra√±o se da cuenta". La palabra clave aqu√≠ es "Redeem" (Redimir/Rescatar). Frethorne quiere romper su contrato de servidumbre (indenture). Plan A: Pide a sus padres que paguen directamente a los comerciantes para cancelar su contrato. Plan B (Comercio): Si no tienen dinero ("if you cannot get the merchants to redeem me"), les propone un negocio. Les pide que hagan una colecta (get a gathering) entre vecinos para comprar comida (carne, queso, mantequilla) y envi√°rsela a Virginia. Frethorne no solo pide comida para alimentarse, la pide para venderla. Dice: "Any eating meat will yield great profit" (Cualquier carne comestible dar√° gran beneficio). En la Virginia de 1623, la comida escaseaba tanto que val√≠a mucho m√°s que el dinero. Su plan es recibir esa comida, venderla en la colonia y usar las ganancias (profit) para comprar su propia libertad. Es fascinante ver c√≥mo Frethorne da instrucciones muy t√©cnicas sobre c√≥mo enviar la mercanc√≠a, lo que demuestra lo dif√≠cil que era el transporte transatl√°ntico: El queso: Debe ser "very old cheese" (queso muy curado) para que aguante el viaje. El embalaje: Les instruye poner "cooper‚Äôs chips" (virutas de madera de tonelero) entre cada queso. La raz√≥n: Si no lo hacen, el calor de la bodega del barco (the heat of the hold) har√° que se pudran (rot). El p√°rrafo termina con una nota muy oscura que refleja la realidad de la mortalidad en la colonia: Frethorne promete ser honesto con las ganancias (deal truly with you). Pero a√±ade: "y si muero antes de que llegue [la comida]". Ha dejado instrucciones a Goodman Jackson para que, si Richard muere antes de que llegue el env√≠o, Jackson venda la comida y devuelva el dinero a los padres en Inglaterra. Esto demuestra que Frethorne sabe que la muerte es inminente. En resumen: Este p√°rrafo es un grito de auxilio disfrazado de plan de negocios. Frethorne les est√° diciendo a sus padres: "Me equivoqu√© al venir, un extra√±o me cuida mejor que ustedes, env√≠enme mercanc√≠a para comprar mi libertad o morir√© aqu√≠ pronto".Good father, do not forget me, but have mercy and pity my miserable case. I know if you did but see me, you would weep to see me; for I have but one suit.... Wherefore, for God‚Äôs sake, pity me. I pray you to remember my love to all my friends and kindred. I hope all my brothers and sisters are in good health, and as for my part I have set down my resolution that certainly will be; that is, that the answer of this letter will be life or death to me. Therefore good father, send as soon as you can; and if you send me any thing let this be the mark.ROTRichard Frethorne,Martin's HundredAll these died out of my master‚Äôs house, since I came; and we came in but at Christmas, and this is the 20th day of March. And the sailors say that there is two-thirds of the 150 dead already. And thus I end, praying to God to send me good success that I may be redeemed out of Egypt. So vale in Christo.Loving father, I pray you to use this man very exceeding kindly, for he hath done much for me, both on my journey and since. I entreat you not to forget me, but by any means redeem me; for this day we hear that there is 26 of Englishmen slain by the Indians. And they have taken a pinnace of Mr. Pountis, and have gotten pieces, armor, swords, all things fit for war; so that they may now steal upon us and we cannot know them from English till it is too late‚Äîthat they be upon us‚Äîand then there is no mercy. Therefore if you love or respect me as your child, release me from the bondage and save my life. Now you may save me, or let me be slain with infidels. Ask this man‚Äîhe knoweth that all is true and just that I say here. If you do redeem me, the Company must send for me to my Mr. Harrod; for so is this Master‚Äôs name. April, the second day.Your loving son,Richard FrethorneMoreover, on the third day of April we heard that after these rogues had gotten the pinnace and had taken all furnitures [such] as pieces, swords, armor, coats of mail, powder, shot and all the things that they had to trade withal, they killed the Captain and cut off his head. And rowing with the tail of the boat foremost, they set up a pole and put the Captain‚Äôs head upon it, and so rowed home. Then the Devil set them on again, so that they furnished about 200 canoes with above 1000 Indians, and came, and thought to have taken the ship; but she was too quick for them‚Äîwhich thing was very much talked of, for they always feared a ship. But now the rogues grow very bold and can use pieces, some of them, as well or better than an Englishman; for an Indian did shoot with Mr. Charles, my master‚Äôs kinsman, at a mark of white paper, and he hit it at the first, but Mr. Charles could not hit it. But see the envy of these slaves, for when they could not take the ship, then our men saw them threaten Accomack, that is the next plantation. And now there is no way but starving: . . . For they had no crop last year by reason of these rogues, so that we have no corn but as ships do relieve us, nor we shall hardly have any crop this year; and we are as like to perish first as any plantation. For we have but two hogsheads of meal left to serve us this two months, . . . that is but a halfpennyloaf a day for a man. Is it not strange to me, think you? But what will it be when we shall go a month or two and never see a bit of bread, as my master doth say we must do? And he said he is not able to keep us all. Then we shall be turned up to the land and eat barks of trees or molds of the ground; therefore with weeping tears I beg of you to help me. Oh, that you did see my daily and hourly sighs, groans, and tears, and thumps that I afford mine own breast, and rue and curse the time of my birth, with holy Job. I thought no head had been able to hold so much water as hath and doth daily flow from mine eyes.But this is certain: I never felt the want of father and mother till now; but now, dear friends, full well I know and rue it, although it were too late before I knew it....Your loving son,Richard FrethorneVirginia, 3rd April, Explicaci√≥nEste fragmento es la conclusi√≥n de la carta y constituye la parte m√°s dram√°tica y desesperada. Aqu√≠ Frethorne narra el colapso total de la seguridad en la colonia debido a la guerra con los nativos y la hambruna inminente. Aqu√≠ te explico los puntos clave que est√°n ocurriendo en este texto: Frethorne comienza actualizando el recuento de bajas. El dato: Llegaron en Navidad con 150 personas. Para el 20 de marzo, los marineros estiman que dos tercios ya han muerto. "Redeemed out of Egypt": Frethorne usa una met√°fora b√≠blica. Compara su situaci√≥n en Virginia con la esclavitud de los israelitas en el Egipto fara√≥nico. Pedir ser "redimido de Egipto" significa ser rescatado de la esclavitud y la muerte. El 2 de abril y el 3 de abril, la situaci√≥n empeora dr√°sticamente. El robo estrat√©gico: Los nativos (a los que llama "rogues" o bribones) capturaron una pinaza (un barco peque√±o de exploraci√≥n) perteneciente al Sr. Pountis. Con el barco, consiguieron un arsenal: armaduras, espadas, p√≥lvora y armas de fuego. Guerra psicol√≥gica: Frethorne relata una escena de terror. Los nativos mataron al Capit√°n, le cortaron la cabeza y la pusieron en un poste en el barco capturado, remando con la popa hacia adelante para exhibir el trofeo mientras regresaban a su territorio. El ataque masivo: Envalentonados, reunieron 200 canoas y 1000 guerreros para intentar capturar el barco principal, aunque no lo lograron. Esta es quiz√°s la parte que m√°s miedo le da a Frethorne. Adaptaci√≥n ind√≠gena: Los colonos depend√≠an de sus armas de fuego ("pieces") para mantener la ventaja. Sin embargo, Frethorne admite que ahora los nativos "se han vuelto muy audaces y pueden usar las armas... tan bien o mejor que un ingl√©s". La prueba: Cuenta una an√©cdota humillante donde un nativo compiti√≥ disparando a un blanco de papel contra el Sr. Charles (pariente del amo de Frethorne). El nativo acert√≥ al primer intento, mientras que el ingl√©s fall√≥. Esto significaba que los colonos ya no estaban seguros ni siquiera con sus mosquetes. Debido a la guerra, no pudieron plantar cultivos el a√±o anterior y no pueden plantar este a√±o porque los nativos los acechan. Raciones: Solo quedan dos barriles (hogsheads) de harina para dos meses. Eso equivale a medio panecillo ("halfpenny loaf") al d√≠a por persona. Medidas desesperadas: Su amo ha admitido que no puede mantenerlos a todos. Frethorne anticipa que pronto los echar√°n al campo a comer "cortezas de √°rboles o moho de la tierra" (barks of trees or molds of the ground). El texto termina con Frethorne llorando, golpe√°ndose el pecho y maldiciendo el momento de su nacimiento, compar√°ndose con el Santo Job (figura b√≠blica que lo perdi√≥ todo y sufri√≥ plagas). Termina con una confesi√≥n desgarradora: nunca valor√≥ a sus padres hasta ahora, cuando ya es demasiado tarde. En resumen, este fragmento explica por qu√© la carta es tan urgente: no se trata solo de trabajo duro, se enfrentan a un enemigo que ha aprendido a usar sus propias armas y a una hambruna que los obligar√° a comer tierra.**Footnotes: Shrovetide: The three days before Ash Wednesday, former76ly set aside as a period of confession and a time of festivity preceding Lent in Christian77 practice. Gilead: A region east of the Jordan River settled in biblical times by, among others, Is87raelites who were successfully defended in battle against vastly superior numbers of invaders by Judas Maccabeus and his warriors. Pinnace: A small sailing boat, often used as a scout for a larger vessel.

item.title: 02.3_Winthrop, John - A Model of Christian Charity
item.description:
02.4_Vocabulario y Conceptos Hist√≥ricos - Winthrop John - A Model of Christian CharityJohn Winthrop, "A Modell of Christian Charity"New England's Puritans dissented not only from the Church of England, but from England's social and political order as well. Seeking alternatives to established institutions, they turned on the one hand to Scripture and on the other to their common experience for precedents. Of this extraordinarily learned and articulate group (the Massachusetts Bay Colony in the seventeenth century boasted more college graduates per capita than England itself), few gave more careful thought to the purposes of the Puritans' "errand into the wilderness" or to the proper foundations for the colony's institutions than, John Winthrop (1588-1649).Winthrop was a representative of the new gentry that flourished under the Tudor regime. His grandfather, Adam Winthrop, was a country boy who went to London, made a fortune as a clothier, and then purchased a manor (one of the many properties seized by Henry VIII from the church). His son, also named Adam, trained as a lawyer, but spent his life farming and governing his estate in Suffolk. The habit of governing others came naturally to John Winthrop. After attending Trinity College, Cambridge for two years, he returned home, where he was appointed Justice of the Peace and, a few years later, steward -- in which capacity he acted as his father's chief financial and administrative officer.Despite his privileged position, John Winthrop, like many other educated Englishmen of the period, became increasingly disenchanted with corrupt and oppressive Stuart monarchy. When Charles I decided in the spring of 1629 to rule without parliamentary consent, imprisoned Puritan parliamentary leaders, and banned Puritans from the practice of law, Winthrop decided to emigrate.While en route to New England in 1630, on board the Arabella, Winthrop wrote an essay on charity (which he presumably preached as a sermon) which sought to apply scriptural virtues to the peculiar circumstances and challenges the colonists would face in creating their new social and political order. A number of themes which become central to American philanthropic traditions are first articulated here: 1) efforts to reconcile the problem of spiritual and political equality with economic inequality; 2) concerns about the relations between the good of individuals and the good of the community; 3) the conception of community as a voluntary -- contractual -- bond between individuals; 4) a focus on the particular obligations of the rich towards the poor; 4) the conception of mission as the basis for formulating specific institutional goals and objectives.It is important to note that Winthrop does not mention private institutions: he, like many Puritans, rejected the idea of endowed institutions because of their association with Stuart corruption. For him, charity retains an interpersonal rather than an institutional emphasis. Further, he assumes that the work of society will be done by public institutions of church and State. Notably, Winthrop did not suggest that charity should extend beyond the convenanted group of believers. The notion of universal benevolence would have to wait until a more enlightened age.A Modell of Christian CharityWrittenOn board the Arabella,On the Atlantic Ocean.By the Honorable JOHN WINTHROP Esquire.In his passage, (with a great Company of Religious People,of which Christian Tribes he was the Brave Leader and famousGovernor;) from the Island of Great Brittaine, to New Englandin North America. Anno 1630.God Almightie in his most holy and wise providence hath so disposed of the Condicion of mankind, as in all times some must be rich some poore, some high and eminent in power and dignitie; others meane and in subjection.THE REASON HEREOF.
Reas: First, to hold conformity with the rest of his works, being delighted to shewe forthe the glory of his wisdome in the variety and difference of the Creatures and the glory of his power, in ordering all these differences for the preservacion and good of the whole, and the glory of his greatnes that as it is the glory of princes to have many officers, soe this great King will have many Stewards counting himselfe more honored in dispenceing his guifts to man by man, than if he did it by his owne immediate hand. Reas: Secondly, That he might have the more occasion to manifest the work of his Spirit: first, upon the wicked in moderateing and restraineing them; so that the riche and mighty should not eate upp the poore, mor the poore, and dispised rise up against their superiours, and shake off theire yoake; 2ly in the regenerate in exerciseing his graces in them, as in the greate ones, their love mercy, gentlenes, temperance etc., in the poore and inferior sorte, theire faithe patience, obedience, etc.Explicaci√≥nEsta secci√≥n es fundamental porque Winthrop est√° respondiendo a la pregunta teol√≥gica: "¬øPor qu√© Dios permite (o dise√±a) que haya desigualdad social, con unos muy ricos y otros muy pobres?" Aqu√≠ te explico punto por punto lo que Winthrop argumenta en esos dos p√°rrafos: Winthrop argumenta que la desigualdad es una decisi√≥n est√©tica y administrativa de Dios. La Gloria de la Variedad: Dios se deleita en la diversidad de sus criaturas (animales, plantas, estrellas). De la misma manera, quiere ver variedad en la humanidad (diferentes niveles de riqueza y poder) para mostrar la gloria de su sabidur√≠a. La Preservaci√≥n del Todo: Winthrop cree que estas diferencias est√°n ordenadas para "la preservaci√≥n y el bien del todo". Es decir, la sociedad funciona como una m√°quina donde cada pieza tiene un tama√±o diferente para que el mecanismo funcione. La Met√°fora del Rey y los Mayordomos (Stewards): Esta es la parte clave. Winthrop dice que un Pr√≠ncipe glorioso no hace todo el trabajo √©l mismo; tiene muchos "oficiales". De igual modo, Dios (el Gran Rey) usa a los ricos como "Stewards" (Administradores/Mayordomos). El concepto: Dios podr√≠a dar dinero directamente a los pobres por un milagro ("his owne immediate hand"), pero prefiere darle el dinero a los ricos para que ellos lo distribuyan ("dispenceing his guifts to man by man"). Esto honra m√°s a Dios porque crea una cadena de servicio. Aqu√≠ Winthrop explica la funci√≥n moral de la desigualdad. Dios usa la diferencia de clases para controlar a los malvados y perfeccionar a los buenos ("los regenerados"). Winthrop tiene una visi√≥n pesimista de la naturaleza humana. Sin el control divino y la estructura social: Los Ricos: Se comer√≠an vivos a los pobres ("eate upp the poore"). Es una met√°fora de explotaci√≥n extrema. Los Pobres: Se rebelar√≠an violentamente contra sus superiores ("rise up against their superiours") y sacudir√≠an su yugo ("shake off theire yoake"). Conclusi√≥n: La estructura social, mantenida por el Esp√≠ritu de Dios, evita que la sociedad se convierta en una guerra civil constante. Para los "regenerados" (los buenos cristianos), la desigualdad es necesaria porque sin ella no podr√≠an practicar ciertas virtudes espec√≠ficas: En resumen: Si todos fueran ricos, nadie necesitar√≠a misericordia. Si todos fueran pobres, nadie podr√≠a ejercer la caridad. Winthrop dice que Dios cre√≥ la desigualdad para obligar a los humanos a necesitarse unos a otros y as√≠ crear lazos sagrados (el "tejido" o knit del que hablar√° m√°s adelante). Reas: Thirdly, That every man might have need of other, and from thence they might all be knitt more nearly together in the Bond of brotherly affeccion. . . . The deffinition which the Scripture gives us of love is this Love is the bond of perfection. First, it is a bond, or ligament. 2ly, it makes the worke perfect. There is no body but consistes of partes and that which knitts these partes together gives the body its perfeccion, because it makes eache parte soe continguous to other as thereby doe mutually participate with eache other, both in strengthe and infirmity in pleasure and paine, to instance in the most perfect of all bodies, Christ and his church make one body: the severall partes of this body considered aparte before they were united were as disproportionate and as much disordering as so many contrary quallities or elements but when christ comes and by his spirit and love knitts all these partes to himselfe and each to other, it is become the most perfect and best proportioned body in the world. . . .Explicaci√≥n Winthrop presenta la tercera raz√≥n ("3. Reas: Thirdly") de por qu√© existen ricos y pobres: El Prop√≥sito de la Escasez: La raz√≥n de la desigualdad es "que cada hombre pueda tener necesidad del otro" (That every man might have need of other). El Resultado: Al necesitarse mutuamente (el pobre necesita ayuda, el rico necesita a alguien a quien servir), se crea un v√≠nculo inevitable. De esta necesidad nace el "V√≠nculo de afecto fraternal" (Bond of brotherly affeccion). Interpretaci√≥n: Si todos fueran ricos y poderosos, vivir√≠an aislados en su independencia. La desigualdad fuerza la comunidad. Winthrop ofrece una definici√≥n casi m√©dica o anat√≥mica del amor, basada en las Escrituras (The deffinition which the Scripture gives us of love): El Amor es un Tejido Conectivo: Lo define expl√≠citamente como un "ligamento" (bond, or ligament). Funci√≥n del Ligamento: Un cuerpo se compone de partes. Sin ligamentos, esas partes ser√≠an solo un mont√≥n de huesos y carne sueltos. El amor es lo que "teje" (knitts) estas partes juntas y le da al cuerpo su perfecci√≥n. Contig√ºidad y Empat√≠a: El ligamento hace que las partes est√©n tan unidas (contiguous) que "participan mutuamente" (mutually participate) en lo que le pasa a la otra. Si una parte siente dolor (paine) o placer (pleasure), o tiene fuerza (strengthe) o enfermedad (infirmity), el resto del cuerpo lo siente. Esto es una llamada a la empat√≠a radical. Winthrop usa el ejemplo teol√≥gico m√°ximo para ilustrar su punto social: "el cuerpo m√°s perfecto de todos, Cristo y su iglesia hacen un solo cuerpo" (the most perfect of all bodies, Christ and his church make one body). Antes de la Uni√≥n (Caos): Consideradas por separado, las partes (las personas) son "desproporcionadas" y "desordenadas" (disproportionate and as much disordering), como elementos contrarios chocando entre s√≠. Un individuo sin comunidad es un caos. Despu√©s de la Uni√≥n (Perfecci√≥n): Cuando Cristo viene y, mediante su Esp√≠ritu y amor, "teje" (knitts) todas estas partes consigo mismo y entre ellas, se convierte en el cuerpo "mejor proporcionado del mundo". Here in are 4 things to be propounded: first the persons, 2ly, the worke, 3ly, the end, 4ly, the meanes. For the persons, wee are a Company professiong our selves fellow members of Christ. In which respect onely though wee were absent from eache other many miles, and had our imploymentes as farre distant, yet wee ought to account ourselves knitt toether by this bond of love, and live in the Aqu√≠ tienes la transcripci√≥n de las p√°ginas restantes (3, 4, 5 y 6). He mantenido la ortograf√≠a y puntuaci√≥n del ingl√©s antiguo (por ejemplo: "prividence", "Condicion", "2ly", "Citty") tal como aparece en el documento original. Explicaci√≥n Finalmente, Winthrop baja de la teolog√≠a a la realidad de su viaje: Qui√©nes son: Se definen como una Compa√±√≠a que profesa ser "miembros compa√±eros de Cristo" (fellow members of Christ). La Regla de la Distancia: Argumenta que, gracias a este "ligamento", la distancia f√≠sica no importa. Aunque est√©n ausentes el uno del otro por muchas millas (absent from eache other many miles), deben considerarse "tejidos juntos" (knitt toether) por este v√≠nculo de amor. En resumen: Winthrop est√° diciendo que la sociedad que est√°n fundando no es una empresa comercial ni una simple ciudad; es un organismo vivo. Si cortas el "ligamento" (el amor/caridad) ignorando las necesidades del vecino, el cuerpo se desmorona y muere.excercise of it, if wee would have the comforte of our being in Christ. . . .2ly. for the worke wee have in hand, it is by mutuall consent through a speciall overruleing providence, and amore then an ordinary approbation of the Churches of Christ to seeke out a place ofCohabitation and Consorteshipp under a due forme of Government both civall and ecclesiasticall. In such cases as this the care of the publique must oversway all private respects, by which not onely conscience, but meare Civil policy doth bind1e us; for it is a true rule that perticuler estates cannott subsist in the ruine of the publique.SummaryEsta secci√≥n es el "plan de acci√≥n" pr√°ctico y espiritual de Winthrop. Aqu√≠ define qu√© van a hacer, por qu√© lo hacen y c√≥mo deben comportarse para sobrevivir. "seeke out a place of Cohabitation and Consorteshipp under a due forme of Government both civall and ecclesiasticall." Winthrop define la colonia no como un campamento comercial, sino como una sociedad estructurada: Cohabitation and Consorteshipp (Convivencia y Consorcio): No son individuos aislados buscando fortuna, sino socios que han acordado vivir juntos ("Consorteshipp"). Government both civall and ecclesiasticall (Gobierno tanto civil como eclesi√°stico): Winthrop establece desde el principio que necesitar√°n dos tipos de autoridad: Leyes civiles (magistrados, cortes) para el orden p√∫blico. Leyes eclesi√°sticas (iglesia) para el orden espiritual. La Regla de Oro Pol√≠tica: Justo despu√©s, establece la prioridad absoluta: "the care of the publique must oversway all private respects". El bien p√∫blico est√° por encima del inter√©s privado, porque si la colonia ("lo p√∫blico") se arruina, nadie podr√° salvar su propiedad privada ("particular estates"). 3ly. The end is to improve our lives to doe more service to the Lord the comforte and encrease of the body of christe whereof wee are members that our selves and posterity may be the better preserved from the Common corrupcions of this evill world to serve the Lord and worke out our Salvacion under the power and purity of his holy Ordinances.Summary "preserved from the Common corrupcions of this evill world" El objetivo ("The end") no es la riqueza, sino la pureza espiritual. Quieren mejorar sus vidas para servir m√°s a Dios y protegerse a s√≠ mismos y a sus hijos ("posterity") de la corrupci√≥n moral que ve√≠an en Europa e Inglaterra. Buscan vivir bajo "Ordenanzas santas".4ly. for the meanes whereby this must be effected, they are 2fold, a Conformity with the worke and end we aim at, these wee see are extraordinary, therefore wee must not content our selves with usuall ordinary meanes whatsoever wee did or ought to have done when wee lived in England, the same must we doe and more allsoe where we goe. . . .Summary Winthrop advierte que, como el objetivo es extraordinario, los medios tambi√©n deben serlo ("extraordinary"). No basta con ser "buenos cristianos" como lo eran en Inglaterra; deben hacer m√°s. "we must entertaine each other in brotherly Affeccion" Afecto Fraternal: Deben tratarse como familia. Sacrificio Econ√≥mico: Deben estar dispuestos a recortar sus propios excesos ("abridge our selves of our superfluities") para suplir las necesidades de los dem√°s. "make others Condicions our owne rejoyce together" Empat√≠a Total: La frase completa es "make others Condicions our owne, rejoyce together" (hacer nuestras las condiciones de los otros, regocijarnos juntos). Significa que si tu vecino sufre, t√∫ debes sentir ese sufrimiento como propio; si √©l celebra, t√∫ celebras. No hay indiferencia permitida.
. . . wee must be knitt together in this worke as one man, we must entertaine each other in brotherly Affeccion, we must be willing to abridge our selves of our superfluities, for the suppy of others necessities, we must uphold a familiar Commerce together in meekenes, gentlenes, patience and liberallity, wee must delight in eache other, make others Condicions our owne rejoyce together, allwayes haveing before our eyes== our Commission and Community== in the worke. . . . for wee must Consider that wee shall be as a Citty upon a Hill , the eies of all people are uppon us; soe that if wee shall deale falsely with our god in this worke wee have undertaken and soe cause him to withdrawe his present help from us, wee shall be made a story and a by-word through the world, we shall open the mouthes of enemies to speake evill of the wayes of god and all professours for Gods sake; wee shall shame the faces of many of gods worthy servants, and cause theire pra31yers to be turned into Curses upon us till we be consumed out of the good land whether we are going. . . .Summary "always haveing before our eyes our Commission and Community in the worke" Commission (La Comisi√≥n): Winthrop ve esto como un contrato legal con Dios. Dios les ha dado el permiso y los recursos para ir; ellos a cambio prometen construir una sociedad santa. El Riesgo: Si rompen el contrato ("deale falsely with our god"), Dios retirar√° su ayuda y perecer√°n. "wee shall be as a Citty upon a Hill, the eies of all people are uppon us" Esta es la conclusi√≥n famosa y terrible: Visibilidad Total: Ser una "Ciudad sobre una Colina" no es un premio, es una responsabilidad de alto riesgo. Significa que no pueden esconderse. El Juicio Mundial: "Los ojos de todos los pueblos est√°n sobre nosotros". Si tienen √©xito: Glorifican a Dios. Si fracasan: Se convertir√°n en una "historia y un refr√°n" (story and a by-word) de burla por todo el mundo. Avergonzar√°n a Dios y sus oraciones se convertir√°n en maldiciones hasta que sean "consumidos" (destruidos) de la tierra. Resumen: Winthrop les est√° diciendo: "Hemos firmado un contrato estricto con Dios. Si nos cuidamos unos a otros (amor fraternal) y ponemos a la comunidad primero, sobreviviremos y seremos un ejemplo. Si somos ego√≠stas, todo el mundo nos ver√° fracasar y moriremos".Source: Edmund S. Morgan, ed., The Founding of Massachusetts: Historians and the Sources (Indianapolis, 1964).Additional Readings: David Grayson Allen, In English Ways: The Movement of Societies and the Transferal of English Local Law and Custom (Chapel Hill, 1981).David T. Konig, Law and Society in Puritan Massachusetts (1979)Perry Miller, Errand Into the Wilderness (Boston, 1956).__, The New England Mind: From Colony to Province (Boston, 1953).__, Orthodoxy in Massachusetts, 1630-1650 (New York, 1970).Edmund S. Morgan, Puritan Dilemma: The Story of John Winthrop (New York, 1958).Samuel Eliot Morison, Builders of the Bay Colony (Boston, 1930).Darrett Rutman, Winthrop's Boston (Chapel Hill, 1965). item.title: 02.4_Vocabulario y Conceptos Hist√≥ricos - Winthrop John - A Model of Christian Charity
item.description: Estos t√©rminos son esenciales para entender el contexto pol√≠tico, religioso y social del serm√≥n de Winthrop. Puritans (Puritanos): Grupo de protestantes ingleses de los siglos XVI y XVII que buscaban "purificar" la Iglesia de Inglaterra de pr√°cticas cat√≥licas romanas. En el texto, se les describe como disidentes que buscaban alternativas a las instituciones establecidas. Gentry: Una clase social brit√°nica constituida por terratenientes acomodados ("caballeros") que estaban justo por debajo de la nobleza. Winthrop es descrito como un representante de la "new gentry" (nueva clase acomodada). Steward (Mayordomo/Administrador): En el contexto hist√≥rico, era el administrador financiero principal de una finca o mansi√≥n. En el contexto teol√≥gico del texto, Winthrop usa la met√°fora de que los ricos son "God's Stewards" (Administradores de Dios), lo que significa que su riqueza no les pertenece, sino que la administran en nombre de Dios para ayudar a los pobres. Citty upon a Hill (Ciudad sobre una colina): Referencia b√≠blica (Mateo 5:14). Es la frase m√°s famosa del documento. Significa que la colonia de Massachusetts estar√≠a expuesta a la vista de todo el mundo y deb√≠a ser un modelo perfecto de caridad cristiana; si fallaban, ser√≠an una verg√ºenza mundial. Stuart Monarchy (Monarqu√≠a Estuardo): La casa real (Jacobo I, Carlos I) que gobernaba Inglaterra. Los puritanos, incluido Winthrop, se opon√≠an a ellos por considerarlos corruptos y opresivos ("corrupt and oppressive"). Covenant (Pacto/Convenio): Aunque la palabra expl√≠cita usada a veces es "Commission" o "Bond", el concepto central es el Covenant. Es la idea de que el grupo tiene un contrato sagrado con Dios: si cumplen las reglas, prosperan; si no, son destruidos. El texto presenta una ortograf√≠a inestable (t√≠pica antes de la estandarizaci√≥n de los diccionarios en el s. XVIII). Sufijos con "-e" muda: Es muy com√∫n ver una "e" extra al final de las palabras que hoy no existe. Ejemplos: woorke (work), owne (own), poore (poor), falsely (falsely - aqu√≠ se mantiene, pero en otras como greate), kind (kinde). Intercambio "i/y" y "u/v": Citty: City. Prividence: Providence (Providencia). Guifts: Gifts (regalos/dones). Terminaciones en "-cion" en lugar de "-tion": Condicion: Condition. Affecion: Affection. Corrupcions: Corruptions. Salvacion: Salvation. Abreviaturas num√©ricas: 2ly, 3ly, 4ly: Abreviatura de Secondly, Thirdly, Fourthly (En segundo lugar, etc.). Estas palabras existen hoy, pero Winthrop las usa con un significado diferente: Meane (Mean): Hoy significa "malo/cruel" o "promedio". En este texto significa humilde, de bajo estatus social o pobre. Contexto: "...others meane and in subjection" (otros humildes y en sumisi√≥n). Ligament / Knit (Ligamento / Tejer o Unir): Winthrop usa una met√°fora biol√≥gica y textil constante. La sociedad es un "cuerpo" y el amor es el "ligamento" que mantiene unidas las partes. Frase clave: "knitt together in this worke as one man" (unidos/tejidos en este trabajo como un solo hombre). Superfluities: Cosas superfluas. Se refiere al exceso de riqueza o lujos. Winthrop dice que los colonos deben sacrificar sus "superfluities" para ayudar a otros en necesidad. Professours (Professors): No significa "profesores acad√©micos". En el siglo XVII, un professor era alguien que profesaba abiertamente su fe cristiana. Contexto: "...speake evill of the wayes of god and all professours" (hablar mal de los caminos de Dios y de todos los creyentes). Conversation / Commerce: En el texto se usa "Commerce together" y "Cohabitation". En este contexto, no se refiere solo a negocios, sino a la interacci√≥n social diaria y la convivencia entre vecinos. Errand: Usado en la introducci√≥n moderna ("errand into the wilderness"). Significa una misi√≥n o encargo con un prop√≥sito espec√≠fico, no simplemente un "recado" trivial como se entiende hoy. En la P√°gina 4, Winthrop argumenta que una sociedad no es simplemente un grupo de individuos viviendo cerca, sino un organismo vivo. El Problema de las Partes Sueltas: Winthrop explica que las partes de un cuerpo, consideradas por separado, son "desproporcionadas" y "ca√≥ticas" (disproportionate and as much disordering). Es decir, un individuo (rico o pobre) sin comunidad es in√∫til y monstruoso. El Amor como Ligamento: Aqu√≠ usa un t√©rmino anat√≥mico preciso para la √©poca. Dice que el amor es un "ligamento" (ligament). En anatom√≠a, los ligamentos unen los huesos y permiten el movimiento. Winthrop sostiene que sin este "ligamento de amor", el cuerpo social se deshace. No es un adorno sentimental, es la estructura que impide que la colonia se desmorone. Sensibilidad Compartida: La prueba de que este cuerpo funciona es la transmisi√≥n de sensaciones. Dice que las partes deben "participar mutuamente... tanto en fuerza y debilidad, en placer y dolor" (mutually participate... in strengthe and infirmity in pleasure and paine). Significado: Si el pobre sufre hambre, el rico debe sentir ese "dolor" f√≠sicamente. Si el rico ignora al pobre, el cuerpo est√° enfermo (paralizado o insensible). Esta es una de las im√°genes m√°s repetidas en el texto (aparece en las p√°ginas 3, 4 y 5). La Acci√≥n de Tejer: Winthrop repite que deben ser "knitt together" (tejidos juntos). La Unidad Absoluta: En la P√°gina 5, la met√°fora llega a su punto m√°ximo cuando dice: "Wee must be knitt together in this worke as one man" (Debemos estar tejidos en este trabajo como un solo hombre). Ya no son "muchos colonos", son un solo hombre. Esto implica que la diversidad de clases (ricos/pobres) debe fundirse en una sola voluntad para sobrevivir. Winthrop aterriza estas met√°foras religiosas en una regla pol√≠tica dura y pragm√°tica en la P√°gina 5: "Particular estates cannott subsist in the ruine of the publique." (Los patrimonios particulares no pueden subsistir en la ruina de lo p√∫blico). La L√≥gica: Usando la met√°fora del cuerpo, explica que si el cuerpo muere (la colonia fracasa), el brazo (el individuo rico) tambi√©n muere. Por lo tanto, el ego√≠smo no solo es pecado, es suicidio. La Regla de Oro: "The care of the publique must oversway all private respects" (El cuidado de lo p√∫blico debe dominar sobre cualquier inter√©s privado). Winthrop no estaba pidiendo "amabilidad". Estaba dise√±ando un sistema de supervivencia. Anatom√≠a: La sociedad es un cuerpo. Fisiolog√≠a: El amor es el ligamento y el sistema nervioso que conecta las partes. Patolog√≠a: El ego√≠smo es una enfermedad que corta los ligamentos; si ocurre, el cuerpo se desmiembra y muere. Conclusi√≥n del serm√≥n. Esta es la parte m√°s dram√°tica y famosa del texto, donde Winthrop deja de usar met√°foras amables sobre el "cuerpo" y pasa a un lenguaje legal y apocal√≠ptico de "vida o muerte".Winthrop plantea la migraci√≥n no como un viaje, sino como un contrato estricto (Covenant) firmado con Dios.En la P√°gina 6, Winthrop utiliza el t√©rmino "Commission". En el lenguaje legal de la √©poca, una "comisi√≥n" era un documento oficial que otorgaba autoridad para realizar una tarea espec√≠fica, pero bajo condiciones estrictas. T√©rminos estrictos: Winthrop advierte que han hecho un pacto especial con Dios para esta misi√≥n. Dice: "If wee shall deale falsely with our god in this worke wee have undertaken..." (Si tratamos falsamente con nuestro Dios en este trabajo que hemos emprendido...). La Cl√°usula de Rescisi√≥n: Si fallan en cumplir su parte (vivir en caridad y unidad), Dios "withdrawe his present help from us" (retirar√° su ayuda presente de nosotros). Sin la protecci√≥n divina activa, la colonia est√° condenada. Esta es la frase m√°s c√©lebre de todo el documento, pero a menudo se malinterpreta hoy en d√≠a como un s√≠mbolo de orgullo o superioridad. En el contexto de Winthrop (P√°gina 6), era una advertencia sobre la visibilidad total y la presi√≥n extrema. Escrutinio P√∫blico: "The eies of all people are uppon us" (Los ojos de toda la gente est√°n sobre nosotros). El Riesgo de la Verg√ºenza: No dice "seremos un ejemplo brillante", sino que advierte que si fallan, la humillaci√≥n ser√° global. Ser una "ciudad sobre una colina" significa que no tienen d√≥nde esconderse si fracasan. Winthrop detalla un castigo en tres niveles si rompen el pacto: Verg√ºenza Hist√≥rica: Dice que se convertir√°n en "a story and a by-word through the world" (una historia [de burla] y un refr√°n por todo el mundo). Un "by-word" es algo en lo que la gente piensa cuando quiere dar un ejemplo de fracaso. Es decir, se convertir√≠an en el hazmerre√≠r de la historia. Da√±o a la Fe: Su fracaso no solo los afectar√≠a a ellos, sino a Dios. "We shall open the mouthes of enemies to speake evill of the wayes of god" (Abriremos las bocas de los enemigos para hablar mal de los caminos de Dios). Si los puritanos fracasan, sus enemigos en Inglaterra y la Iglesia Cat√≥lica dir√°n: "¬øVieron? Su religi√≥n era falsa". Destrucci√≥n F√≠sica: La advertencia final es la extinci√≥n: "Till we be consumed out of the good land whether we are going" (Hasta que seamos consumidos [eliminados] de la buena tierra a la que vamos). Winthrop est√° diciendo literalmente: si no cuidamos los unos de los otros, moriremos en este desierto. El argumento de Winthrop es que la caridad no es una opci√≥n moral extra, sino un mecanismo de supervivencia pol√≠tica. Si se mantienen unidos ("knitt together"), Dios garantiza el √©xito. Si se dividen por ego√≠smo, rompen la "Comisi√≥n" y enfrentan la destrucci√≥n total.
