item.title: 02.1_Frethorne, Richard - Letter to His Parents
item.description: [...] colonization in the early seventeenth century. Combatting homesickness, disease, hunger, discomfort, and isolation, Frethorne and his fellow settlers struggled to make a success of their fledgling community. As might be expected, many longed to be "redeemed out of Egypt" and return to their former lives across the Atlantic. Frethorne's correspondence reveals the poignancy of the struggle for survival waged by the class of indentured servants in the new world. ‚Äî Lisbeth Cohen, Montana State University Loving and kind father and mother:My most humble duty remembered to you, hoping in God of your good health, as I myself am at the making hereof. This is to let you understand that I your child am in a most heavy case by reason of the nature of the country, [which] is such that it causeth much sickness, as the scurvy and the bloody flux and diverse other diseases, which maketh the body very poor and weak. And when we are sick there is nothing to comfort us; for since I came out of the ship I never ate anything but peas, and loblollie (that is, water gruel). As for deer or venison I never saw any since I came into this land. There is indeed some fowl, but we are not allowed to go and get it, but must work hard both early and late for a mess of water gruel and a mouthful of bread and beef. A mouthful of bread for a penny loaf must serve for four men which is most pitiful....People cry out day and night‚ÄîOh! that they were in England without their limbs‚Äîand would not care to lose any limb to be England again, yea, though they beg from door to door. For we live in fear of the enemy every hour, yet we have had a combat with them on the Sunday before Shrovetide,^1 and we took two alive and made slaves of them. But it was by policy, for we are in great danger; for our plantation is very weak by reason of the death and sickness of our company. For we came but twenty for the merchants, and they are half dead just; and we look every hour when two more should go. Yet there came some four other men yet to live with us, of which there is but one alive; and our Lieutenant is dead, and his father and his brother. And there was some five or six of the last year‚Äôs twenty, of which there is but three left, so that we are fain to get other men to plant with us; and yet we are but 32 to fight against 3000 if they should come. And the nighest help that we have is ten miles of us, and when the rogues overcame this place last they slew 80 persons. How then shall we do, for we lie even in their teeth? They may easily take us, but that God is merciful and can save with few as well as with many, as he showed to Gilead.^2 ...And I have nothing to comfort me, nor there is nothing to be gotten here but sickness and death, except that one had money to lay out in some things for profit. But I have nothing at all‚Äîno, not a shirt to my back but two rags (2), nor no clothes but one poor suit, nor but one pair of shoes, but one pair of stockings, but one cap, but two bands. My cloak is stolen by one of my own fellows, and to his dying hour [he] would not tell me what he did with it; but some of my fellows saw him have butter and beef out of a ship, which my cloak, I doubt [not], paid for. So that I have not a penny, nor a penny worth, to help me to either spice or sugar or strong waters, without the which one cannot live here. For as strong beer in1 England doth fatten and strengthen them, so water here doth wash and weaken these here [and] only keeps life and soul together. 2But I am not half a quarter so strong as I was in England, and all is for want of victuals; for I do protest unto you that I have eaten more in [one] day at home than I have allowed me here for a week. You have given more than my day‚Äôs allowance to a beggar at the door: and if Mr. Jackson had not relieved me, I should be in a poor case. But he like a father and she like a loving mother doth still help me.3...Goodman Jackson pitied me and made me a cabin to lie in... which comforted me more than peas or water gruel. Oh, they be very godly folks, and love me very well, and will do anything for me. And he much marvelled that you would send me a servant to the Company; he saith I had been better knocked on the head. And indeed so I find it now, to my great grief and misery; and saith that if you love me you will redeem me suddenly, for which I do entreat and beg. And if you cannot get the merchants to redeem me for some little money, then for God‚Äôs sake get a gathering or entreat some good folks to lay out some little sum of money in meal and cheese and butter and beef. Any eating meat will yield great profit. Oil and vinegar is very good; but, father, there is great loss in leaking. But for God‚Äôs sake send beef and cheese and butter, or the more of one sort and none of another. But if you send cheese, it must be very old cheese; and at the cheesemonger‚Äôs you may buy very good cheese for two pence farthing or halfpenny, that will be liked very well. But if you send cheese, you must have a care how you pack it in barrels; and you must put cooper‚Äôs chips between every cheese, or else the heat of the hold will rot them. And look whatsoever you send me‚Äîbe it never so much‚Äîlook, what[ever] I make of it, I will deal truly with you. I will send it over and beg the profit to redeem me; and if I die before it come, I have entreated Goodman Jackson to send you the worth of it, who hath promised he will....Explicaci√≥nEsta es una de las partes m√°s conmovedoras y reveladoras de la carta. Aqu√≠, Richard Frethorne deja de lado las descripciones generales de la colonia para hablar de su estrategia personal de supervivencia y lanzar una s√∫plica desesperada (y manipuladora) a sus padres. Aqu√≠ te explico los puntos clave de este fragmento desglosados por temas: Frethorne introduce a un tal Sr. Jackson (Goodman era un t√≠tulo para hombres respetables pero no nobles). El contraste: Mientras sus propios padres lo enviaron a sufrir, este extra√±o lo "compadeci√≥" (pitied me), le construy√≥ una caba√±a y lo trat√≥ como a un hijo. La cr√≠tica indirecta: Frethorne usa a Jackson para criticar a sus padres sin hacerlo directamente. Dice que Jackson "se maravill√≥" de que sus padres lo hubieran enviado como sirviente y dijo que "habr√≠a sido mejor que me golpearan en la cabeza" (better knocked on the head). Es una forma brutal de decir: "Enviarme aqu√≠ fue una sentencia de muerte, y hasta un extra√±o se da cuenta". La palabra clave aqu√≠ es "Redeem" (Redimir/Rescatar). Frethorne quiere romper su contrato de servidumbre (indenture). Plan A: Pide a sus padres que paguen directamente a los comerciantes para cancelar su contrato. Plan B (Comercio): Si no tienen dinero ("if you cannot get the merchants to redeem me"), les propone un negocio. Les pide que hagan una colecta (get a gathering) entre vecinos para comprar comida (carne, queso, mantequilla) y envi√°rsela a Virginia. Frethorne no solo pide comida para alimentarse, la pide para venderla. Dice: "Any eating meat will yield great profit" (Cualquier carne comestible dar√° gran beneficio). En la Virginia de 1623, la comida escaseaba tanto que val√≠a mucho m√°s que el dinero. Su plan es recibir esa comida, venderla en la colonia y usar las ganancias (profit) para comprar su propia libertad. Es fascinante ver c√≥mo Frethorne da instrucciones muy t√©cnicas sobre c√≥mo enviar la mercanc√≠a, lo que demuestra lo dif√≠cil que era el transporte transatl√°ntico: El queso: Debe ser "very old cheese" (queso muy curado) para que aguante el viaje. El embalaje: Les instruye poner "cooper‚Äôs chips" (virutas de madera de tonelero) entre cada queso. La raz√≥n: Si no lo hacen, el calor de la bodega del barco (the heat of the hold) har√° que se pudran (rot). El p√°rrafo termina con una nota muy oscura que refleja la realidad de la mortalidad en la colonia: Frethorne promete ser honesto con las ganancias (deal truly with you). Pero a√±ade: "y si muero antes de que llegue [la comida]". Ha dejado instrucciones a Goodman Jackson para que, si Richard muere antes de que llegue el env√≠o, Jackson venda la comida y devuelva el dinero a los padres en Inglaterra. Esto demuestra que Frethorne sabe que la muerte es inminente. En resumen: Este p√°rrafo es un grito de auxilio disfrazado de plan de negocios. Frethorne les est√° diciendo a sus padres: "Me equivoqu√© al venir, un extra√±o me cuida mejor que ustedes, env√≠enme mercanc√≠a para comprar mi libertad o morir√© aqu√≠ pronto".Good father, do not forget me, but have mercy and pity my miserable case. I know if you did but see me, you would weep to see me; for I have but one suit.... Wherefore, for God‚Äôs sake, pity me. I pray you to remember my love to all my friends and kindred. I hope all my brothers and sisters are in good health, and as for my part I have set down my resolution that certainly will be; that is, that the answer of this letter will be life or death to me. Therefore good father, send as soon as you can; and if you send me any thing let this be the mark.ROTRichard Frethorne,Martin's HundredAll these died out of my master‚Äôs house, since I came; and we came in but at Christmas, and this is the 20th day of March. And the sailors say that there is two-thirds of the 150 dead already. And thus I end, praying to God to send me good success that I may be redeemed out of Egypt. So vale in Christo.Loving father, I pray you to use this man very exceeding kindly, for he hath done much for me, both on my journey and since. I entreat you not to forget me, but by any means redeem me; for this day we hear that there is 26 of Englishmen slain by the Indians. And they have taken a pinnace of Mr. Pountis, and have gotten pieces, armor, swords, all things fit for war; so that they may now steal upon us and we cannot know them from English till it is too late‚Äîthat they be upon us‚Äîand then there is no mercy. Therefore if you love or respect me as your child, release me from the bondage and save my life. Now you may save me, or let me be slain with infidels. Ask this man‚Äîhe knoweth that all is true and just that I say here. If you do redeem me, the Company must send for me to my Mr. Harrod; for so is this Master‚Äôs name. April, the second day.Your loving son,Richard FrethorneMoreover, on the third day of April we heard that after these rogues had gotten the pinnace and had taken all furnitures [such] as pieces, swords, armor, coats of mail, powder, shot and all the things that they had to trade withal, they killed the Captain and cut off his head. And rowing with the tail of the boat foremost, they set up a pole and put the Captain‚Äôs head upon it, and so rowed home. Then the Devil set them on again, so that they furnished about 200 canoes with above 1000 Indians, and came, and thought to have taken the ship; but she was too quick for them‚Äîwhich thing was very much talked of, for they always feared a ship. But now the rogues grow very bold and can use pieces, some of them, as well or better than an Englishman; for an Indian did shoot with Mr. Charles, my master‚Äôs kinsman, at a mark of white paper, and he hit it at the first, but Mr. Charles could not hit it. But see the envy of these slaves, for when they could not take the ship, then our men saw them threaten Accomack, that is the next plantation. And now there is no way but starving: . . . For they had no crop last year by reason of these rogues, so that we have no corn but as ships do relieve us, nor we shall hardly have any crop this year; and we are as like to perish first as any plantation. For we have but two hogsheads of meal left to serve us this two months, . . . that is but a halfpennyloaf a day for a man. Is it not strange to me, think you? But what will it be when we shall go a month or two and never see a bit of bread, as my master doth say we must do? And he said he is not able to keep us all. Then we shall be turned up to the land and eat barks of trees or molds of the ground; therefore with weeping tears I beg of you to help me. Oh, that you did see my daily and hourly sighs, groans, and tears, and thumps that I afford mine own breast, and rue and curse the time of my birth, with holy Job. I thought no head had been able to hold so much water as hath and doth daily flow from mine eyes.But this is certain: I never felt the want of father and mother till now; but now, dear friends, full well I know and rue it, although it were too late before I knew it....Your loving son,Richard FrethorneVirginia, 3rd April, Explicaci√≥nEste fragmento es la conclusi√≥n de la carta y constituye la parte m√°s dram√°tica y desesperada. Aqu√≠ Frethorne narra el colapso total de la seguridad en la colonia debido a la guerra con los nativos y la hambruna inminente. Aqu√≠ te explico los puntos clave que est√°n ocurriendo en este texto: Frethorne comienza actualizando el recuento de bajas. El dato: Llegaron en Navidad con 150 personas. Para el 20 de marzo, los marineros estiman que dos tercios ya han muerto. "Redeemed out of Egypt": Frethorne usa una met√°fora b√≠blica. Compara su situaci√≥n en Virginia con la esclavitud de los israelitas en el Egipto fara√≥nico. Pedir ser "redimido de Egipto" significa ser rescatado de la esclavitud y la muerte. El 2 de abril y el 3 de abril, la situaci√≥n empeora dr√°sticamente. El robo estrat√©gico: Los nativos (a los que llama "rogues" o bribones) capturaron una pinaza (un barco peque√±o de exploraci√≥n) perteneciente al Sr. Pountis. Con el barco, consiguieron un arsenal: armaduras, espadas, p√≥lvora y armas de fuego. Guerra psicol√≥gica: Frethorne relata una escena de terror. Los nativos mataron al Capit√°n, le cortaron la cabeza y la pusieron en un poste en el barco capturado, remando con la popa hacia adelante para exhibir el trofeo mientras regresaban a su territorio. El ataque masivo: Envalentonados, reunieron 200 canoas y 1000 guerreros para intentar capturar el barco principal, aunque no lo lograron. Esta es quiz√°s la parte que m√°s miedo le da a Frethorne. Adaptaci√≥n ind√≠gena: Los colonos depend√≠an de sus armas de fuego ("pieces") para mantener la ventaja. Sin embargo, Frethorne admite que ahora los nativos "se han vuelto muy audaces y pueden usar las armas... tan bien o mejor que un ingl√©s". La prueba: Cuenta una an√©cdota humillante donde un nativo compiti√≥ disparando a un blanco de papel contra el Sr. Charles (pariente del amo de Frethorne). El nativo acert√≥ al primer intento, mientras que el ingl√©s fall√≥. Esto significaba que los colonos ya no estaban seguros ni siquiera con sus mosquetes. Debido a la guerra, no pudieron plantar cultivos el a√±o anterior y no pueden plantar este a√±o porque los nativos los acechan. Raciones: Solo quedan dos barriles (hogsheads) de harina para dos meses. Eso equivale a medio panecillo ("halfpenny loaf") al d√≠a por persona. Medidas desesperadas: Su amo ha admitido que no puede mantenerlos a todos. Frethorne anticipa que pronto los echar√°n al campo a comer "cortezas de √°rboles o moho de la tierra" (barks of trees or molds of the ground). El texto termina con Frethorne llorando, golpe√°ndose el pecho y maldiciendo el momento de su nacimiento, compar√°ndose con el Santo Job (figura b√≠blica que lo perdi√≥ todo y sufri√≥ plagas). Termina con una confesi√≥n desgarradora: nunca valor√≥ a sus padres hasta ahora, cuando ya es demasiado tarde. En resumen, este fragmento explica por qu√© la carta es tan urgente: no se trata solo de trabajo duro, se enfrentan a un enemigo que ha aprendido a usar sus propias armas y a una hambruna que los obligar√° a comer tierra.**Footnotes: Shrovetide: The three days before Ash Wednesday, former76ly set aside as a period of confession and a time of festivity preceding Lent in Christian77 practice. Gilead: A region east of the Jordan River settled in biblical times by, among others, Is87raelites who were successfully defended in battle against vastly superior numbers of invaders by Judas Maccabeus and his warriors. Pinnace: A small sailing boat, often used as a scout for a larger vessel.

item.description: vocabulario hist√≥rico clave extra√≠do de los textos de Richard Frethorne y Thomas Morton. He organizado los t√©rminos por categor√≠as para facilitar su comprensi√≥n, incluyendo el t√©rmino original en ingl√©s, su traducci√≥n aproximada y el contexto hist√≥rico espec√≠fico.Estos t√©rminos aparecen principalmente en la carta de Frethorne y reflejan las duras condiciones de Virginia. Bloody flux (Flujo sangriento): Un t√©rmino hist√≥rico para la disenter√≠a, una enfermedad intestinal grave que causaba diarrea con sangre. Era una de las principales causas de muerte en las colonias. Scurvy (Escorbuto): Enfermedad causada por la deficiencia de vitamina C, com√∫n entre marineros y colonos debido a la falta de frutas y verduras frescas. Loblollie / Water gruel (Gachas aguadas): Una papilla muy l√≠quida y sin sustancia hecha de agua y granos (avena o ma√≠z). Frethorne se queja de que esto es lo √∫nico que comen. Victuals (Vituallas/Provisiones): Alimentos o provisiones necesarias para la vida. Hogsheads (Bocoyes): Barriles grandes utilizados para transportar mercanc√≠as (tabaco, harina, l√≠quidos). Frethorne menciona que solo les quedan dos "hogsheads" de harina. Conceptos clave para entender la jerarqu√≠a en la colonia. Indentured servant (Sirviente contratado/por contrato): Aunque no aparece la frase exacta en el texto, el contexto describe esta condici√≥n. Eran personas que firmaban un contrato trabajando gratis durante a√±os (generalmente 4-7) a cambio del pasaje a Am√©rica, comida y alojamiento. Frethorne es uno de ellos. Goodman: Un t√≠tulo de cortes√≠a utilizado para dirigirse a un hombre de posici√≥n social respetable, pero inferior a la de un caballero ("Gentleman" o "Mr."). Ejemplo: "Goodman Jackson". Fellows (Compa√±eros): En este contexto, se refiere a otros sirvientes o trabajadores del mismo rango que Frethorne. Redeem (Redimir/Rescatar): Frethorne ruega a sus padres que lo "rediman", es decir, que paguen su contrato para liberarlo de su servidumbre antes de tiempo. Pinnace (Pinaza): Una embarcaci√≥n de vela ligera, utilizada a menudo como exploradora para barcos m√°s grandes o para navegar en aguas poco profundas (r√≠os y bah√≠as). Pieces (Piezas/Armas de fuego): Se refiere a mosquetes o armas de fuego ("fowling pieces"). Frethorne menciona que los nativos han conseguido "pieces". Shot (Perdigones/Munici√≥n): Proyectiles para las armas de fuego. Cooper‚Äôs chips (Virutas de tonelero): Astillas de madera utilizadas para rellenar espacios vac√≠os en los barriles y evitar que el contenido (como el queso) se pudriera por el calor o la humedad. Estos t√©rminos son m√°s relevantes en la secci√≥n sobre Thomas Morton y el conflicto en Nueva Inglaterra. Separatist (Separatista): Puritanos radicales (como los Peregrinos de Plymouth) que deseaban separarse completamente de la Iglesia de Inglaterra, a diferencia de otros puritanos que quer√≠an reformarla desde dentro. Puritan (Puritano): Grupo protestante ingl√©s que buscaba "purificar" la Iglesia de Inglaterra de pr√°cticas cat√≥licas. Eran conocidos por su rigidez moral. Maypole (Palo de mayo): Un poste alto decorado con flores y cintas, centro de festividades folcl√≥ricas tradicionales inglesas. Los puritanos lo consideraban una pr√°ctica pagana e inmoral (Morton erigi√≥ uno en Merry-mount). Shrovetide (Carnestolendas): Los tres d√≠as previos al Mi√©rcoles de Ceniza (inicio de la Cuaresma). Era una √©poca tradicional de festejos que Frethorne menciona como fecha de un combate. Rogues (Bribones/P√≠caros): Frethorne usa este t√©rmino de manera despectiva para referirse a los nativos americanos. Betwixt (Entre): Forma arcaica de "between". Fain (Dispuesto/Obligado): Estar dispuesto a hacer algo por necesidad ("we are fain to get other men"). Panegyric (Paneg√≠rico): Un discurso o texto de alabanza excesiva (mencionado en el an√°lisis literario sobre Morton).

item.description:
Etiquetas: #identidad #examen_final #comparativa
Links: Winthrop_A_Model_of_Christian_Charity | Crevecoeur_What_is_an_AmericanLa identidad americana evoluciona desde una misi√≥n colectiva y religiosa excluyente en el siglo XVII (Puritanos) hacia una identidad individualista, secular y agraria en el siglo XVIII (Ilustraci√≥n).
Winthrop_A_Model_of_Christian_Charity (1630): La uni√≥n se basa en un pacto religioso ("Covenant"). La comunidad es como un cuerpo donde cada parte debe ayudarse por amor cristiano ("ligaments of love"). [cite_start]La desigualdad es natural y deseada por Dios para fomentar la caridad[cite: 96].
